description: The first organized movement for women’s political equality in the West
events: Seneca Falls Convention of 1848; first birth control clinic opened in 1916; the passage of the 15th amendment in 1870 that granted Black men the right to vote. Angered white women, so they began the push for suffrage for themselves; the 19th amendment passed in 1920 which granted (in theory) all women the right to vote.
characteristics: Began as unified with the abolitionist movement   Became a movement only for white women
event2: 1870- Passage of the 15th Amendment, granting Black men the right to vote.
event4: 1920- Passage of the 19th Amendment, granting white women the right to vote.

description: The second wave of feminism focused on financial and sexual liberation for women
events: Betty Friedan published The Feminine Mystique in 1963; Equal Pay Act passed in 1963 which, in theory, outlawed the gender pay gap; Roe v. Wade guaranteed reproductive freedom in 1973;
goals: Outlaw marital rape, raise awareness of domestic abuse, combat sexual harassment in the workplace
characteristics: The feminist movement began to intertwine with anti-capitalist and anti-racist movements, but the second wave still catered toward middle-class white women.
event2: 1963- Congress passes Equal Pay Act, which in theory outlaws the gender pay gap.
event3: 1973- Supreme Court case Roe v Wade guarantees women the right to reproductive freedom.

description: The third wave of feminism advocated for an increase in women in leadership roles especially in the workplace
events: Anita Hill testified that Supreme Court justice nominee Clarence Thomas sexually harassed her in 1991; 1992 became known as “the year of the woman” after a record number of women won seats in congress; emergence of riot grrrls in 1990s
goals: No specific goals or accomplishments define the third wave of feminism
characteristics: Intersectionality became an increasingly important part of the feminist movement
event2: 1991- Anite Hill testifies that Supreme Court nominee Clarence Thomas sexually harrassed her.
event3: 1992- Declared "The Year of the Woman" after a record number of women won seats in Congress.

description: The fourth wave of feminism uses technology and mass communication to advocate for women in unprecedented ways
events: #MeToo movement, including the ousting of Bill Cosby, Harvey Weinstein and Kevin Spacey; The Women’s March has drawn millions of people to participate since 2017; record numbers of women elected to public office
goals: Target the systems of patriarchal oppressions instead of trying to accomplish specific goals
characteristics: The Women’s March has drawn millions of people to participate since 2017; record numbers of women elected to public office
event2: 2017- Women's March draws millions of people to protest the inauguration of President Donald Trump.
event3: 2018- Record of women elected to Congress.
